subject: Real Estate
title: Plazas and the Power of Public Space
description: A short lesson to help you apply Plazas and the Power of Public Space.

hook.text: In 1961, New York offered developers a deal: add a public plaza and get extra floors on your building.

buildup.text: The incentive produced hundreds of plazas. Most were hostile: windswept, empty, and clearly unwelcoming.

discovery.text: Sociologist William Whyte studied what makes plazas work: sunlight, movable seating, food vendors, and shade.

twist.text: Developers intentionally made plazas uncomfortable to discourage homeless people and keep corporate tenants happy.

climax.text: A good public space generates foot traffic, retail sales, and community. A bad one just wastes land.

punchline.text: A bench, sun, and a food cart make a plaza alive.

quiz.question: What did William Whyte find makes public plazas successful?
